4fabeba81715f8697f538888e6b141ac.description: The Kawanishi H8K[a] was a flying boat used by the Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service during World War II for maritime patrol duties. The Allied reporting name for the type was "Emily".

variants.name: H8K1 Experimental Type 13 Large-sized Flying boat (13試大型飛行艇 13-Shi Ōgata Hikōtei)
variants.description: One prototype and four supplementary prototypes. Prototype was mounted Mitsubishi Mk4A Kasei 11 engines, supplementary prototype was mounted Mitsubishi MK4B Kasei 12 engines. Supplementary prototypes were renamed Type 2 Flying Boat Model 11 on 5 February 1942. Prototype was rebuilt to H8K1-L in November 1943.

variants.name: H8K1 Type 2 Flying boat, Model 11 (二式飛行艇11型 Nishiki Hikōtei 11-gata)
variants.description: Developed on 5 February 1942. First operative model of series, 12 produced. Mounted Mitsubishi MK4B Kasei 12 engines.
Rebuilt from H8K1 prototype. Fitted augment exhausts. Up to 41 passengers.

variants.name: H8K2 Type 2 Flying boat, Model 12 (二式飛行艇12型 Nishiki Hikōtei 12-gata)
variants.description: Developed on 26 June 1943. Mounted Mitsubishi MK4Q Kasei 22 engines and improved tail gun turret. Latter batch was equipped with Air-Surface Vessel (ASV) search radar, and removed side gun blisters. 112 produced.[13]
Transport version of H8K2. Initial named Type 2 Transport Flying Boat, Model 32. Armaments were 1 × forward-firing 20 mm cannon and 1 × rearward-firing 13 mm machine gun. Up to 64 passengers.

variants.name: H8K3 Provisional name Type 2 Flying Boat, Model 22 (仮称二式飛行艇22型 Kashō Nishiki Hikōtei 22-gata)
variants.description: Experimental version, H8K2 modified. Equipped with retractable floats in wingtips, Fowler flaps, sliding hatch side gun locations in place of the blisters and a retractable dorsal turret, all in an effort to increase speed; two prototypes only (work number 596 and 597).

variants.name: H8K4 Provisional name Type 2 Flying Boat, Model 23 (仮称二式飛行艇23型 Kashō Nishiki Hikōtei 23-gata)
variants.description: H8K3 re-engined with 1,825 hp MK4T Mitsubishi Kasei 25b engines, two converted from H8K3.
Transport version of H8K4. Only a project, because all H8K4s were lost in March 1945.[further explanation needed]

variants.name: G9K
variants.description: Proposed land-based attack bomber variant, only a project.

5c9677a4dce9d7a648d98600a7570936.name: Mitsubishi F1M Type 0 Observation Seaplane
5c9677a4dce9d7a648d98600a7570936.title: Mitsubishi F1M
5c9677a4dce9d7a648d98600a7570936.description: The Mitsubishi F1M (Allied reporting name "Pete") was a Japanese reconnaissance floatplane of World War II. It was the last biplane type of the Imperial Japanese Navy, with 944 built between 1936 and 1944. The Navy designation was "Type Zero Observation Seaplane" (零式水上観測機).

variants.name: F1M1
variants.description: Prototypes. Four built.

variants.name: F1M2
variants.description: Two-seat reconnaissance floatplane for the Imperial Japanese Navy.

variants.name: F1M2-K
variants.description: Two-seat training version.

f736600d743c6ded14ccec07c358facc.name: Nakajima C6N Saiun Navy Carrier Reconnaissance Plane
f736600d743c6ded14ccec07c358facc.title: Nakajima C6N
f736600d743c6ded14ccec07c358facc.description: The Nakajima C6N Saiun (彩雲, "Iridescent Cloud") was a carrier-based reconnaissance aircraft used by the Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service in World War II. Advanced for its time, it was the fastest carrier-based aircraft put into service by Japan during the war. The Allied reporting name was Myrt.

variants.name: C6N1 Experimental Type 17 carrier reconnaissance plane (17試艦上偵察機, 17-Shi Kanjō Teisatsuki)
variants.description: Three prototypes and sixteen supplementary prototypes produced, four-blade propeller; latter batch were equipped three-blade propeller, mounted Nakajima NK9K-L Homare 22 engine, No. 6 was mounted Nakajima NK9H Homare 21 engine. Renamed Test production Saiun (試製彩雲, Shisei Saiun) in July 1943.

variants.name: C6N1 Saiun Model 11 (彩雲11型, Saiun 11-gata)
variants.description:
General production model. Three-blade propeller, mounted Nakajima NK9H Homare 21 engine.
C6N1-B Saiun Model 21 (彩雲21型, Saiun 21-gata)
Proposed torpedo bomber version. Only a project.
C6N1 Saiun Model 11 night fighter variant (彩雲11型改造夜戦, Saiun 11-gata Kaizō yasen)
Temporary rebuilt two-seat night fighter version; this was not a regulation naval aircraft. Development code C6N1-S was not discovered in the IJN official documents. One model with a single 30 mm Type 2 cannon was built in June 1945,[8] and at least five models with ×2 20 mm Type 99-1 cannon were converted from standard C6N1 models. One surviving example of the ×2 20mm cannon variant is stored in the Paul E. Garber Preservation, Restoration, and Storage Facility. The 30 mm version was only used to attack B-29s once, on August 1, 1945. The destructive power of the Type 2 cannon extended to twisting the skin of the Saiun's lightweight fuselage.[8]

variants.name: C6N2 Test production Saiun Kai/Saiun Model 12 (試製彩雲改/彩雲12型, Shisei Saiun Kai/Saiun 12-gata)
variants.description: Fitted with four-blade propeller, 1,980 PS (1,456 kW) Nakajima NK9L-L Homare 24-Ru turbocharged engine. The Hitachi 92 turbocharger was fitted with the aim of improving high altitude performance; target speed was 345 kn (639 km/h; 397 mph) at 8,500 m (27,900 ft). One prototype (コ–C6T1) was converted from a regular C6N1 in February 1945 and first flew in July of that year. The installation of an oil cooler and an intercooler necessitated a sizable cowling to be installed beneath the engine.[9]

variants.name: C6N3 Test production Saiun Kai 1 (試製彩雲改1, Shisei Saiun Kai 1)
variants.description: Proposed high-altitude night fighter version of the C6N2. Dual 20 mm cannons were installed. Only a project.

variants.name: C6N4 Test production Saiun Kai 2 (試製彩雲改2, Shisei Saiun Kai 2)
variants.description: Fitted 2,200-hp Mitsubishi MK9A Ha 43-11 Ru turbocharged engine, one prototype was converted from C6N1, incomplete.

variants.name: C6N5 Test production Saiun Kai 3 (試製彩雲改3, Shisei Saiun Kai 3)
variants.description: Proposed torpedo bomber version. Only a project.

variants.name: C6N6 Test production Saiun Kai 4 (試製彩雲改4, Shisei Saiun Kai 4)
variants.description: Wooden aircraft model. Only a project.

9485ab021626a90953417a7911d0bcdc.name: Nakajima E8N Navy Type 95 Reconnaissance Seaplane Model 1
9485ab021626a90953417a7911d0bcdc.title: Nakajima E8N
9485ab021626a90953417a7911d0bcdc.description: The Nakajima E8N was a Japanese ship-borne, catapult-launched, reconnaissance seaplane of the Second Sino-Japanese War. It was a single-engine, two-seat biplane with a central main-float and underwing outriggers. During the Pacific War, it was known to the Allies by the reporting name "Dave".

variants.name: E8N1
variants.description: Initial production type, powered by 433 kW (580 hp) Nakajima Kotobuki 2 Kai 1 radial engine.

variants.name: E8N2
variants.description: Improved production type, with more powerful (470 kW/630 hp) Nakajima Kotobuki Kai 2 engine.

439faabb9cbb57ad9a597ee4aea90f03.name: Nakajima J1N Gekkou Navy Type 2 Reconnaissance Plane
439faabb9cbb57ad9a597ee4aea90f03.title: Nakajima J1N
439faabb9cbb57ad9a597ee4aea90f03.description: The Nakajima J1N1 Gekkō (月光, "Moonlight") is a twin-engine aircraft used by the Japanese Imperial Navy during World War II and was used for reconnaissance, night fighter, and kamikaze missions. The first flight took place in May 1941. It was given the Allied reporting name "Irving", since the earlier reconnaissance version the J1N1-C, was mistaken for a fighter.

variants.name: J1N1
variants.description: J1N1 : Three seaters long-range fighter. Two of prototypes and seven of supplementary prototypes.

variants.name: J1N1 KAI
variants.description: J1N1 KAI : Night Fighter converted from J1N1.

variants.name: J1N1-CJ1N1-R
variants.description: J1N1-C : Long-range reconnaissance aircraft. Later re-designated J1N1-R.

variants.name: J1N1-C KAI
variants.description: J1N1-C KAI : Night Fighter converted from J1N1-C.

variants.name: J1N1-R
variants.description: J1N1-R : Long-range reconnaissance aircraft.

variants.name: J1N1-F
variants.description: J1N1-F : Observation aircraft. A little number of prototypes only. Equipped G5N2 turret or G4M2 turret.

variants.name: J1N1-S
variants.description: J1N1-S : Night fighter aircraft. Armed with 2 × 20 mm forward up-firing Type 99 cannons and 2 × 20 mm forward under-firing Type 99 cannons.

variants.name: J1N1-Sa
variants.description: J1N1-Sa : Night Fighter same as above, armed with 3 × 20 mm forward up-firing Type 99 cannons.

ab905d490acf6ffcec33cea49b21e96b.name: Watanabe E9W Navy Type 96 Small Reconnaissance Seaplane
ab905d490acf6ffcec33cea49b21e96b.title: Watanabe E9W
ab905d490acf6ffcec33cea49b21e96b.description: The Watanabe E9W was a Japanese submarine-borne reconnaissance seaplane, the first aircraft designed by Watanabe Ironworks.

53fd9aa5673a64d43fbd09feac616b96.name: Yokosuka E14Y Type 0 Small Reconnaissance Seaplane
53fd9aa5673a64d43fbd09feac616b96.title: Yokosuka E14Y
53fd9aa5673a64d43fbd09feac616b96.description: The Yokosuka E14Y (Allied reporting name Glen) was an Imperial Japanese Navy reconnaissance seaplane transported aboard and launched from Japanese submarine aircraft carriers such as the I-25 during World War II. The Japanese Navy designation was "Type 0 Small Reconnaissance Seaplane" (零式小型水上偵察機).

21e4c6e5822fe16b639c19b342757c2a.name: Kawasaki Ki-56 Army Type 1 Freight Transport & Tachikawa Navy Type LO
21e4c6e5822fe16b639c19b342757c2a.title: Kawasaki Ki-56
21e4c6e5822fe16b639c19b342757c2a.description: The Kawasaki Ki-56 (Japanese: 一式貨物輸送機, Type 1 Freight Transport) was a Japanese two-engine light transport aircraft used during World War II. It was known to the Allies by the reporting name "Thalia". 121 were built between 1940 and 1943.

9ef9792550e9a93d4f43d3aa8c84a4ac.name: Mitsubishi Ki-57 Army Type 100 Transport
9ef9792550e9a93d4f43d3aa8c84a4ac.title: Mitsubishi Ki-57
9ef9792550e9a93d4f43d3aa8c84a4ac.description: The Mitsubishi Ki-57 was a Japanese passenger transport aircraft, developed from the Ki-21 bomber, during the early 1940s.

variants.description: Ki-57-I Army Type 100 Transport Model 1: Powered by two 708 kW (949 hp) Nakajima Ha5 KAI radial engines and a redesigned fuselage to accommodate 11 passengers. About 100 aircraft of this type were built including the civil version.
MC-20-I: Same as above but built for civil use with Imperial Japanese Airways (Dai Nippon Koku KK).

Ki-57-II Army Type 100 Transport Model 2:Powered by two 805 kW (1,080 hp) Mitsubishi Ha-102 Zuisei 14-cylinder radial engines installed in redesigned nacelles. Minor equipment and detail refinements were also incorporated. 306 aircraft of this type were produced before the end of production in January 1945.
MC-20-II: Same as above but built for civil use with Imperial Japanese Airways (Dai Nippon Koku KK).
L4M1: A small number of Ki-57-Is were transferred for test by the Japanese navy as transports and were redesignated L4M1.

a09dedeca1979e5ad68450e09ce17bb2.name: Nakajima Ki-34 Army Type 97 Transport & Nakajima L1N Navy Type AT-2 Transport
a09dedeca1979e5ad68450e09ce17bb2.title: Nakajima Ki-34
a09dedeca1979e5ad68450e09ce17bb2.description: The Nakajima Ki-34 was a Japanese light transport of World War II. It was a twin-engine, low-wing monoplane; the undercarriage was of tailwheel type with retractable main units. During the Pacific War, the Allies assigned the type the reporting name Thora.

380cb4fe0510f19c4b0da699e38464f2.name: Showa/Nakajima L2D Navy Type 0 Transport
380cb4fe0510f19c4b0da699e38464f2.title: Showa/Nakajima L2D
380cb4fe0510f19c4b0da699e38464f2.description: The Shōwa L2D and Nakajima L2D, given the designations Shōwa Navy Type 0 Transport and Nakajima Navy Type 0 Transport(零式輸送機), were license-built versions of the Douglas DC-3. The L2D series, numerically, was the most important Japanese transport in World War II. The L2D was given the Allied code name Tabby.

25e6f490b1c1a844ebc4391de5c32f23.name: Kyushu J7W Shinden
25e6f490b1c1a844ebc4391de5c32f23.title: Kyushu J7W Shinden
25e6f490b1c1a844ebc4391de5c32f23.description: The Kyūshū J7W Shinden (震電, "Magnificent Lightning")  was a World War II Japanese propeller-driven prototype fighter with wings at the rear of the fuselage, a nose-mounted canard, and pusher engine.

47171b62ddca0c0f679fbb1971d2bff4.name: Mitsubishi Ki-83
47171b62ddca0c0f679fbb1971d2bff4.title: Mitsubishi Ki-83
47171b62ddca0c0f679fbb1971d2bff4.description: The Mitsubishi Ki-83 (キ83) was a Japanese experimental long range heavy fighter designed near the end of World War II. It did not reach production status.

variants.name: Ki-83
variants.description: Ki-83 experimental long-range heavy fighter, four prototypes built.

variants.name: Ki-95
variants.description: Ki-95 projected reconnaissance version, none built.[6]

variants.name: Ki-103
variants.description: Ki-103 projected development, none built.[6]

de041d095242f256140ae59e7c9f5c04.name: Mitsubishi J8M
de041d095242f256140ae59e7c9f5c04.title: Mitsubishi J8M
de041d095242f256140ae59e7c9f5c04.description: The Mitsubishi J8M Shūsui (Japanese: 三菱 J8M 秋水, literally "Autumn Water", used as a poetic term meaning "Sharp Sword" deriving from the swishing sound of a sword) is a Japanese World War II rocket-powered interceptor aircraft closely based on the German Messerschmitt Me 163 Komet. Built as a joint project for both the Navy and the Army Air Services, it was designated J8M (Navy) and Ki-200 (Army).

ea06fcb4f2580f4ff8f77d46203f1ada.name: Nakajima G8N
ea06fcb4f2580f4ff8f77d46203f1ada.title: Nakajima G8N
ea06fcb4f2580f4ff8f77d46203f1ada.description: The Nakajima G8N Renzan (連山, "Mountain Range") was a four-engine long-range bomber designed for use by the Imperial Japanese Navy. The Navy designation was "Type 18 land-based attack aircraft" (十八試陸上攻撃機); the Allied code name was "Rita".

variants.name: G8N1
variants.description: G8N1 : Four-engine heavy bomber. Production version.

variants.name: G8N2
variants.description: G8N2 : Modified to carry Ohka Type 33 Special Attack Bomber. Four Mitsubishi MK9A radial engines.

variants.name: G8N3
variants.description: G8N3 : All-steel airframe.

a889ae98a41cb973c8121bab02300ff7.name: Nakajima Ki-87
a889ae98a41cb973c8121bab02300ff7.title: Nakajima Ki-87
a889ae98a41cb973c8121bab02300ff7.description: The Nakajima Ki-87 was a Japanese high-altitude fighter-interceptor of World War II. It was a single seat, exhaust-driven turbo-supercharged engined, low-wing monoplane with a conventional undercarriage.

5afc98ea6e5a36f6fc83acd74baee3f2.name: Tachikawa Ki-94
5afc98ea6e5a36f6fc83acd74baee3f2.title: Tachikawa Ki-94
5afc98ea6e5a36f6fc83acd74baee3f2.description: The Tachikawa Ki-94 was a single-seat fighter-interceptor aircraft project undertaken by the Tachikawa Aircraft Company and to be operated by the Imperial Japanese Army. The project refers to two aircraft designs: the Ki-94-I and the Ki-94-II, both of which did not advance beyond the mock-up and prototype stage respectively.

ab705f484bf3e4959da7af329fc73b13.title: Aichi D1A
ab705f484bf3e4959da7af329fc73b13.name: Aichi D1A
ab705f484bf3e4959da7af329fc73b13.description: The Aichi D1A or Navy Type 94/96 Carrier Bomber (Allied reporting name "Susie") was a Japanese carrier-based dive bomber of the 1930s. A single-engine, two-seat biplane based on the Heinkel He 50, the D1A was produced by Aichi for the Imperial Japanese Navy, remaining in service as a trainer at the time of the attack on Pearl Harbor. The D1A was produced in two variants, the D1A1 (Navy Type 94 Carrier Bomber), and the D1A2 (Navy Type 96 Carrier Bomber, sometimes referred to as the D2A).

variants.name: D1A1 Type 94
variants.description: Powered by 433 kW (580 hp) Nakajima Kotobuki 2 Kai 1 or Kotobuki 3 radial engines; 162 built.[1]

variants.name: D1A2 Type 96 (Sometimes referred to as the D2A)
variants.description: Improved version fitted with spatted wheels and a higher powered Nakajima Hikari 1 engine; 428 built.[1]

variants.name: AB-11
variants.description: Proposed development with retractable undercarriage. Not built.[4]

df900f7276252bc52bd2c0c6bedfcda3.title: Nakajima E2N
df900f7276252bc52bd2c0c6bedfcda3.name: Nakajima E2N
df900f7276252bc52bd2c0c6bedfcda3.description: The Nakajima E2N was a Japanese reconnaissance seaplane of the 1920s. It was a two-seat, single-engine biplane with a central float and underwing stabilizing floats. The E2N served with the Navy as the Nakajima Navy Type 15 Reconnaissance Floatplane (一五式水上偵察機) from 1927 to 1936.

variants.name: E2N1 (Type 15-1 Reconnaissance Seaplane)
variants.description: Short-range reconnaissance aircraft.

variants.name: E2N2 (Type 15-2 Reconnaissance Seaplane)
variants.description: Trainer version with dual controls.

f3d004494d37558684d5d84a54bc5ece.title: Aichi E10A
f3d004494d37558684d5d84a54bc5ece.name: Aichi E10A
f3d004494d37558684d5d84a54bc5ece.description: The Aichi E10A was a Japanese night reconnaissance flying boat of the 1930s.  A single-engined biplane, 15 were built for the Imperial Japanese Navy as the Type 96 Night Reconnaissance Seaplane, serving from 1936 but were retired in 1941 before the Attack on Pearl Harbor.

316880560c7f8b18319f48c2447b3556.title: Aichi E11A
316880560c7f8b18319f48c2447b3556.name: Aichi E11A
316880560c7f8b18319f48c2447b3556.description: The Aichi E11A (九八夜偵, Kyū-hachi Yatei) was an Imperial Japanese Navy flying boat used during the first year of World War II for maritime patrol duties. The Allied reporting name for the type was "Laura"; the Japanese Navy designation was "Type 98 Reconnaissance Seaplane". The Type 98 was quite similar to the earlier E10A Type 96, whose allied name was "Hank". "Lauras" were rare - only 17 were built. It was designed to be launched from cruisers or battleships in order to spot their shellfire at night. The Type 98s were soon diverted to communications and transport duties.

variants.name: E11A1
variants.description: E11A1 : Night reconnaissance flying boat for the Imperial Japanese Navy. Production version.

0e119196dd333a966cf2032d48847caa.title: Nakajima G5N
0e119196dd333a966cf2032d48847caa.name: Nakajima G5N
0e119196dd333a966cf2032d48847caa.description: The Nakajima G5N Shinzan (深山, "Deep Mountain") was a four-engined long-range heavy bomber designed and built for the Imperial Japanese Navy prior to World War II. The Navy designation was "Experimental 13-Shi Attack Bomber"; the Allied code name was "Liz".

variants.name: G5N1 Experimental Type 13 Land-based Attack Bomber "Shinzan" (13試陸上攻撃機 深山 13-Shi Rikujō Kōgekiki "Shinzan")
variants.description: Prototype, two built. Initial named 'Experimental Type 13 Large-size land-based Attack Bomber' (13試大型陸上攻撃機 13-Shi Ōgata Rikujō Kōgekiki). Four-engined heavy bomber/torpedo bomber. Three-blade propeller, mounted four Mitsubishi MK4B Kasei 12 (1,530 hp) radial engines.

variants.name: G5N2 Test production "Shinzan Kai" (試製深山改 Shisei "Shinzan Kai")
variants.description: Supplementary prototype, four built. Four-blade propeller, mounted four Nakajima NK7A Mamori 11 (1,870 hp) radial engines. All G5N2s were rebuilt to G5N2-L in 1943.

variants.name: G5N2-L "Shinzan Kai" Freighter (深山改輸送機 "Sinzan Kai" Yusōki)
variants.description: Long-range Navy transport conversion. All G5N2-Ls were deployed to 1021st Kōkutai, Katori Air Base.

variants.name: Nakajima Ki-68
variants.description: Proposed Army bomber prototype version of the G5N1. Engines were planned Mitsubishi Ha-101, Ha-104, Ha-107, Nakajima Ha-39 or Ha-103 engines. Discontinued in 1941.

variants.name: Kawasaki Ki-85
variants.description: Proposed Army bomber version of the G5N1. Four Mitsubishi Ha-111M engines. Full-scale mock-up was built in 1942, discontinued in May 1943.[1][4]

ddde4e5a488a776c3e285a0af739ff2e.title: Kawanishi H3K
ddde4e5a488a776c3e285a0af739ff2e.name: Kawanishi H3K
ddde4e5a488a776c3e285a0af739ff2e.description: The Kawanishi H3K, also known as Navy Type 90-2 Flying Boat (九〇式二号飛行艇), was a Japanese biplane military flying boat from the interwar period. The H3K was a development of the Short S.8/8 Rangoon. The first of the H3Ks was built by Short Brothers and the remaining four by Kawanishi in Japan.

4d67529969bc1c632374afc790a06140.title: Yokosuka H5Y
4d67529969bc1c632374afc790a06140.name: Yokosuka H5Y
4d67529969bc1c632374afc790a06140.description: The Yokosuka H5Y (short designation) or Yokosuka Navy Type 99 Flying Boat Model 11 (九九式飛行艇, 99shiki hikōtei) (long designation), given the allied code name Cherry, was an IJNAS flying boat in service from 1938.

variants.name: H5Y
variants.description: 2 Prototypes constructed at the Hiro Naval Arsenal

variants.name: H5Y1
variants.description: Production model, 18 built.

variants.name: Yokosuka Navy Type 99 Flying Boat Model 11
variants.description: The long formal designation of the H5Y.

8afb0ea1f873c83ff9883716619646fa.title: Mitsubishi K3M
8afb0ea1f873c83ff9883716619646fa.name: Mitsubishi K3M
8afb0ea1f873c83ff9883716619646fa.description: The Mitsubishi K3M (九〇式機上作業練習機, Kyūrei-shiki kijō sagyō renshūki) was a trainer built by Mitsubishi which was used by the Imperial Japanese Navy in an extremely wide variety of roles, including light transport, liaison aircraft, utility aircraft and occasionally light bomber. Its Allied reporting name was Pine.

variants.name: Mitsubishi K3M1
variants.description: Initial version

variants.name: Mitsubishi K3M2 (Japanese Navy Type 90 Crew Training Aircraft)
variants.description: Initial production version for Imperial Japanese Navy

variants.name: Mitsubishi K3M3 (Japanese Navy Type 90 Crew Training Aircraft)
variants.description: Final production version for Imperial Japanese Navy

variants.name: Mitsubishi K3M3-L
variants.description: Military transport used by Imperial Japanese Navy

variants.name: Ki-7
variants.description: Version for Imperial Japanese Army, 2 built

variants.name: Mitsubishi MS-1
variants.description: Civil transport version

738a2e1e58fcd7bcdf28d078b4ee53cc.title: Yokosuka K5Y
738a2e1e58fcd7bcdf28d078b4ee53cc.name: Yokosuka K5Y
738a2e1e58fcd7bcdf28d078b4ee53cc.description: The Yokosuka K5Y (九三式中間練習機, Kyūsanshikichūkanrenshūki, Type 93 Intermediate Training Aircraft, Allied reporting name: "Willow") was a two-seat unequal-span biplane trainer that served in the Imperial Japanese Navy during World War II. Due to its bright orange paint scheme (applied to all Japanese military trainers for visibility), it earned the nickname "aka-tombo", or "red dragonfly", after a type of insect common throughout Japan.

variants.description: Two-seat intermediate trainer for the Imperial Japanese Navy.
Floatplane version, with Amakaze 11 engine.
Floatplane, with 384 kW (515 hp) Amakaze 21.
Projected land-based version with 358 kW (480 hp) Amakaze 21A. Never built.
Projected land-based version with 384 kW (515 hp) Amakaze 15. Never built.

ffd163fe6045138648b66de9ca8281c8.title: Kyushu K10W
ffd163fe6045138648b66de9ca8281c8.name: Kyushu K10W
ffd163fe6045138648b66de9ca8281c8.description: The Kyushu K10W Type 2 Land based intermediate trainer (Allied reporting name "Oak") was a single engine low wing fixed undercarriage monoplane training aircraft which served in the Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service in the latter part of World War II.

55f64f45bf00ef0b8ce665ca468ea94d.title: Mitsubishi Ki-2
55f64f45bf00ef0b8ce665ca468ea94d.name: Mitsubishi Ki-2
55f64f45bf00ef0b8ce665ca468ea94d.description: The Mitsubishi Ki-2 (九三式双軽爆撃機, Kyūsan-shiki sōkei bakugekiki, "Army Type 93 Twin-engine Light Bomber") was a light bomber built by Mitsubishi for the Imperial Japanese Army Air Service (IJAAS) in the 1930s. Its Allied nickname was "Louise". Despite its antiquated appearance, the Ki-2 was successfully used in Manchukuo and in North China during the early stages of the Second Sino-Japanese War, in areas where danger from enemy fighter aircraft was minimal. It was later used in a training role.

variants.name: Ki-2-I (Army Type 93-I Twin-engined Light Bomber)
variants.description: Initial production variant, powered by two 435 hp (324 kW) Nakajima Kotobuki radial engines; 126 built.

variants.name: Ki-2-II (Army Type 93-II Twin-engined Light Bomber)
variants.description: Final production variant with nose turret and semi-retractable main landing gear, powered by two 559 hp (417 kW) Mitsubishi Ha-8 (Army Type 94 550hp Air Cooled Radial) engines; 61 built.

variants.name: Mitsubishi Ohtori (大鳥, Ōtori, "phoenix", lit. "large bird")
variants.description: A de-militarized long-range record-breaking aircraft operated by Asahi Shimbun; 1 built. Was mistakenly given the Allied reporting name of Eva or Eve.

14db53d4bb7567aac30b377f130c81d5.title: Tachikawa Ki-9
14db53d4bb7567aac30b377f130c81d5.name: Tachikawa Ki-9
14db53d4bb7567aac30b377f130c81d5.description: The Tachikawa Ki-9 (九五式一型練習機, Kyūgo-shiki ichigata renshuki) was an intermediate training aircraft of the Imperial Japanese Army Air Force built by Tachikawa Aircraft Company Ltd in the 1930s. It was known to the Allies under the nickname of "Spruce" during World War II. This aircraft was mistakenly identified as a Tatchikawa by the British.

variants.name: Ki-9 (Army Type 95-1 Medium Grade Trainer Model A)
variants.description: Ki-9 (Army Type 95-1 Medium Grade Trainer Model A): Initial version two-seat intermediate trainer aircraft.

variants.name: Ki-9-ko (Army Type 95-1 Medium Grade Trainer Model B)
variants.description: Ki-9-ko (Army Type 95-1 Medium Grade Trainer Model B): Improved version.

variants.name: Ki-9-otsu (Army Type 95-1 Medium Grade Trainer Model C)
variants.description: Ki-9-otsu (Army Type 95-1 Medium Grade Trainer Model C): Standard production version.

a78d76768bb939641ecbf9d7315e9798.title: Tachikawa Ki-17
a78d76768bb939641ecbf9d7315e9798.name: Tachikawa Ki-17
a78d76768bb939641ecbf9d7315e9798.description: The Tachikawa Ki-17 (九五式三型練習機, Kyugoshiki san-gata renshuki) was a basic training aircraft of the Imperial Japanese Army Air Force built by Tachikawa Aircraft Company Ltd in the 1930s. It was known to the Allies under the nickname of Cedar during World War II.

727a97f8e20ed1600935feca47fbcad2.title: Tachikawa Ki-54
727a97f8e20ed1600935feca47fbcad2.name: Tachikawa Ki-54
727a97f8e20ed1600935feca47fbcad2.description: The Tachikawa Ki-54 was a Japanese twin-engine advanced trainer used during World War II. The aircraft was named Hickory by the Allies.

df7ac11604c0afb10f707778555491eb.title: Tachikawa Ki-55
df7ac11604c0afb10f707778555491eb.name: Tachikawa Ki-55
df7ac11604c0afb10f707778555491eb.description: The Tachikawa Ki-55 was a Japanese advanced trainer.

variants.name: Ki-36
variants.description: Army co-operation aircraft.

variants.name: Ki-72
variants.description: An evolved version with a 447 kW (599 hp) Hitachi Ha38 engine and retractable undercarriage. Not built.

662f70cf84bf2abd62db71a72006b3df.title: Kokusai Ki-59
662f70cf84bf2abd62db71a72006b3df.name: Kokusai Ki-59
662f70cf84bf2abd62db71a72006b3df.description: The Kokusai Ki-59 (一式輸送機, Isshiki-yusōki) was an early 1940s light transport monoplane built by Nippon Kokusai Koku Kogyo K.K for the Imperial Japanese Army as a development of the Teradako-ken TK-3 which had first flown in 1938.

variants.name: TK-3
variants.description: Prototype civil transport with two 640 hp (477 kW) Nakajima Kotobuki 3 radial engines, two built.

variants.name: Ki-59 (Army Type 1 Transport) ("Theresa")
variants.description: Production military transport with two 450 hp (336 kW) Hitachi Ha-13a radial engines, 59 built.

variants.name: Ku-8-I (Army Experimental Glider)
variants.description: Experimental conversion to glider configuration.

variants.name: Ku-8-II (Army Type 4 Large Transport Glider) ("Gander")
variants.description: Assault-glider variant.

0754e25c6ef22495d0ca122431501de8.title: Tachikawa Ki-70
0754e25c6ef22495d0ca122431501de8.name: Tachikawa Ki-70
0754e25c6ef22495d0ca122431501de8.description: The Tachikawa Ki-70 "Clara" was a high speed photo reconnaissance aircraft that was tested for the Japanese Air Force in prototype form but never entered production. The Ki-70 was the intended successor to the Mitsubishi Ki-46 but was difficult to handle and was slower than the Mitsubishi Ki-46. The Ki-70 was first flown in 1943 but was found unsatisfactory and the program was terminated. Three aircraft were built.

0ba7342c85d74c7e553decb3f7096c12.title: Tachikawa Ki-74
0ba7342c85d74c7e553decb3f7096c12.name: Tachikawa Ki-74
0ba7342c85d74c7e553decb3f7096c12.description: The Tachikawa Ki-74 (Allied reporting name "Patsy") was a Japanese experimental long-range reconnaissance bomber of World War II. A twin-engine, mid-wing monoplane, it was developed for the Imperial Japanese Army Air Service but never deployed in combat. The Ki-74 was designed for high altitude operation with a pressurized cabin for its crew.

addbd13e8b7b545529e3f6238ba3215b.title: Kokusai Ki-76
addbd13e8b7b545529e3f6238ba3215b.name: Kokusai Ki-76
addbd13e8b7b545529e3f6238ba3215b.description: The Kokusai Ki-76, or Liaison Aircraft Type 3 (in Japanese: 三式指揮連絡機), was a Japanese high-wing monoplane artillery spotter and liaison aircraft that served in World War II. The Allied reporting name was "Stella".

9e69f0ae7f0a6ca5caa7120bf230343d.title: Kokusai Ku-7
9e69f0ae7f0a6ca5caa7120bf230343d.name: Kokusai Ku-7
9e69f0ae7f0a6ca5caa7120bf230343d.description: The Kokusai Ku-7 Manazuru (真鶴 "white-naped crane"; Allied code-name Buzzard) was a large experimental twin boom Japanese military glider.

09ca41f346c5f72e5533a84ca2306556.title: Kokusai Ku-8
09ca41f346c5f72e5533a84ca2306556.name: Kokusai Ku-8
09ca41f346c5f72e5533a84ca2306556.title_ja: 国際 ク8 四式特殊輸送機
09ca41f346c5f72e5533a84ca2306556.description: The Kokusai Ku-8-II (国際 ク8 四式特殊輸送機, Kokusai ku 8 yonshiki tokushū yusōki) (Kokusai Army Type 4 Special Transport Glider) was a Japanese military glider used during the Second World War. They were usually towed by Mitsubishi G3M or Mitsubishi Ki-21 aircraft.

variants.name: Ku-8-I
variants.description: Ku-8-I:Prototypes.

variants.name: Ku-8-II
variants.description: Ku-8-II:Military transport glider. Production version.

8511d3979da63a09c9a1c5b283e06d29.title: Kyushu Q1W
8511d3979da63a09c9a1c5b283e06d29.name: Kyushu Q1W
8511d3979da63a09c9a1c5b283e06d29.description: The Kyūshū Q1W Tōkai (東海 "Eastern Sea") was a land-based anti-submarine patrol bomber aircraft developed for the Imperial Japanese Navy in World War II. The Allied reporting name was Lorna. Although similar in appearance to the German Junkers Ju 88 medium bomber, the Q1W was a much smaller aircraft with significantly different design details.

variants.name: Q1W1
variants.description: Q1W1 : one prototype.

variants.name: Q1W1 Tokai Model 11
variants.description: Q1W1 Tokai Model 11: main production model.

variants.name: Q1W2 Tokai Model 21
variants.description: Q1W2 Tokai Model 21: version with tail surfaces in wood, built in small numbers.

variants.name: Q1W1-K Tokai-Ren
variants.description: Q1W1-K Tokai-Ren (Eastern Sea-Trainer): trainer with capacity for four, all-wood construction. One prototype built.
